security_audit.summary: This is a documentation-only skill containing instructional content for form optimization. The static scanner produced false positives by misidentifying markdown formatting (backticks) as shell commands and common business terminology as security issues. No executable code or security risks present.

content.value_statement: Forms often lose users due to friction, too many fields, or poor design. This skill provides systematic guidance to audit forms, identify drop-off points, and implement changes that increase completion rates while capturing essential data.
actual_capabilities: Audit existing forms to identify conversion barriers and friction points
Provide field-by-field optimization recommendations based on research
Design multi-step forms that reduce cognitive load and increase completion
Create effective error messages and inline validation guidance
Develop mobile-first form layouts with appropriate touch targets
Generate A/B test hypotheses for form improvements
limitations: Does not implement actual form code or integrations
Does not access analytics data without explicit user input
Does not test forms in live environments
Does not provide legal compliance guidance for data collection

prompt_templates.title: Basic Form Audit
prompt_templates.prompt: I have a [type] form with [number] fields. The current completion rate is [rate]%. Can you audit it and identify the top 5 issues causing drop-off?
prompt_templates.scenario: When user wants a quick assessment of an existing form

prompt_templates.title: New Form Design
prompt_templates.prompt: I need to create a [type] form to capture [data points]. What fields should I include, in what order, and what are the best practices for each field type?
prompt_templates.scenario: When designing a new form from scratch

prompt_templates.title: Mobile Optimization
prompt_templates.prompt: My [type] form has a [X]% lower completion rate on mobile compared to desktop. What mobile-specific changes should I make to improve the mobile experience?

prompt_templates.title: Multi-Step Form Design
prompt_templates.prompt: I have a complex [type] form with [number] fields. Design a multi-step form structure with [number] steps that follows the progressive commitment pattern.
prompt_templates.scenario: When converting a long form to multi-step

output_examples.input: Audit this contact form: 8 fields (name, email, phone, company, role, budget, timeline, message), 15% completion rate on desktop, 8% on mobile.
output: 1. **High Impact** - Too many required fields (8 fields causing 25-50%+ drop-off)
Fix: Reduce to essential 3-4 fields. Make phone, company, budget, and timeline optional.
Fix: Increase touch targets to 44px, use appropriate keyboards, sticky submit button.
3. **Medium Impact** - Sensitive fields early in form
Fix: Move phone, budget, and timeline after email and name.

output_examples.input: Create a multi-step quote request form for a B2B SaaS company.

best_practices: Limit forms to 3-6 fields when possible. Each additional field significantly reduces completion rates.
Start with easiest fields (name, email) to build commitment before asking for sensitive information.
Use single-column layout on mobile with 44px+ touch targets and appropriate keyboard types.
Implement inline validation that triggers on blur, not while typing, to avoid frustrating users.
anti_patterns: Asking for more fields than necessary before demonstrating value to the user.
Using placeholder text as labels, which disappears when users start typing.
Requiring confirmation fields like 'confirm email' that add friction without adding value.
Clearing form data on validation errors, forcing users to re-enter information.

faq.question: How many fields should my form have?
faq.answer: Aim for 3-6 fields maximum. Research shows completion drops 10-25% for 4-6 fields and 25-50%+ for 7+ fields. Consider what you absolutely need before you can help someone versus what you can ask later or infer.

faq.question: Should I use single-column or multi-column form layout?
faq.answer: Single-column layouts consistently outperform multi-column for completion rates, especially on mobile. Only use multi-column for very short related fields like first and last name.

faq.question: How do I reduce mobile form abandonment?
faq.answer: Increase touch targets to at least 44px, use appropriate keyboard types for each field, enable autofill support, use single-column layout, and make the submit button sticky or easily accessible.

faq.question: When should I use a multi-step form?
faq.answer: Multi-step forms work well when you have more than 5-6 logically distinct fields, need conditional paths based on answers, or are collecting complex information like quotes or applications.

faq.question: What makes a good submit button?
faq.answer: Strong buttons tell users exactly what action they will take and what they will receive. Replace generic 'Submit' with action-oriented copy like 'Get My Free Quote' or 'Download the Guide'.

faq.question: How do I handle form errors effectively?
faq.answer: Validate inline as users move between fields, show specific error messages that explain the problem and suggest a fix, position errors near the relevant field, and never clear user input when errors occur.
